if you don't have any agency at all, if everything is luck, and you are just along for the ride, you are not playing a game.
Neither candyland nor snakes and ladders are games, because you have no agency. they are activities.

Note, that if you change the rules of candyland so that you draw two cards, and choose which one to use, it suddenly becomes a game. Or you could roll two dice in snakes and ladders and choose one and it becomes a game.

Not GOOD games, because there is no tension in the choices, but at least they would be games.

Ok ok, so in regards to snakes and ladders, it was a mix of good deeds and sins, as they called karma, but also the idea of reincarnation, if you lead a virtuous life and were lucky, you would be reincarnated at a higher social status such as king, but if you were unlucky, and sinned, you may end up becoming a humble merchant, whatever you are born into the point is to accept this faith as it is your divine role on this earth and everyone has their roll to fulfill, and maybe next time you will be born into something cooler when you reincarnate.

Regarding Liubo/Bo:
A 14 sided shape was thought to be impossible for a very long time, demonstrating once again the mathematical prowess of ancient China.
Also, since 2 of the sides were blank and "unused" (as far as we currently know) in this game; it is safe to assume that the creator of this die just wanted to show off he could create such a shape. :)

Did you notice how so many of the early games are about walking a path and getting home? It's one of the classic styles of games, the "race" game. Other types are the capture game (Chess, Checkers, Hnefatafl to a lesser extent Go,) sowing games (Mancala, where you sow the pieces like seeds around the board.) Other types show up later.

Of course, if you love to gamble, and dice don't cut it for you, there are card games, though they start more like Mahjongg or Dominoes, with tiles. Later dice remained the games for people on the move and sailors, where cards were for more static areas where the cards would not get damaged. That's why Bridge was seen as "Civilized," and why pirates and soldiers play dice for wages.

I have all of those ancient games on my mantle or hanging on my wall, along with Chess, Xiangqi, Shogi, Dominoes, Chess, and Arithmachia, which is a REALLY weird chess style game designed by math cultists in the late classical age. Also the all-mighty card decks, dice sets and dice tower, and such. It's sort of my shrine to gaming.

Most of the actual games I play regularly are in the basement.

Okay, I very much enjoy Crash Course and this version of it, but this guy heavily pronouncing every word that ends in a "d" as though it ends in a "t" is driving my absolutely crazy. "Represennit", "solit", "infiltratet", etc. I understand that this is how a lot of people talk in "black culture", but it sounds ignorant and uneducated. Also, he has another pronunciation pet peeve of mine, saying things that rhyme with "eel" as though they rhyme with "ill". ie: "Dill" for "Deal", "Pill" for "Peel", etc.

I'm sure someone is going to say I'm just being a nitpicky asshole, but it just makes me totally crazy when people butcher languages. It makes any video with this host completely unwatchable to me.

That was part of the inspiration for the theme of ILIOS.

I gotta make a few corrections: You say "ancient Aztecs in south america", but the Aztec triple alliance was located almost entirely in what is now Mexico, the absolute furtherest south it reached was Guatemala, which is still quite a distance from South America.

Additionally, there were no "ancient" Aztecs. The empire itself was formed in the early mid 1400's, and the main city state, that headed the alliance, Tenochtitlan, was only founded in the early 1300's.

Furthermore "In south america Patolli was played by Mesoamerican cultures" is stated; but "mesoamerican" specifically means "middle american", ie: central, not south america. ,
This series is great! Very interesting and super host. Thanks guys!
Ike looks good on the thumbnail

What you said about games connecting with history and with others brought tears to my eyes.

I never knew why I played videogames so much, but they are part of my life, from childhood to right now (I'm in the middle of a pokemon battle). And interestingly, whenever something gamey does something that involves community, I feel very much... serene, almost complete. When Mario made 30 years least year and there was tons of videos of people worldwide about our dearly moustached plumber, I felt really good about sharing the same love for a game with millions of people on the entire planet!

Now I realised this feeling of being part of something isn't just limitless on country borders and cultures and societies, but also limitless about our time and history as humans.

This feeling is quite rare, at least for me, so thank you very very much, Andre and Crash Course team. Keep them comin'!
